title: Movies about Real Places
name: Movies about Real Places
description:
A Map by Baostar

Movies that are prominently about or set in a particular place.

properties.name: Amelie
properties.description: Posted by Baostar Paris, FranceShe\'ll change your life.

properties.name: Angels in America
properties.description: Posted by Baostar New York City, New York"Angels in America" is based on Tony Kushner award-winning play. It is about AIDS, conservative politics, history, relationships, religion, identity (ethnicity, race, homosexuality), love, forgiveness, survival and transcendence. The plot focuses on two trouble couples, one gay, one straight. Their fates quickly become intertwined as the "upheaval" of the story developed. The script is written with beautiful dialogues and the language is stimulating. The production and acting are superb with Al Pacino and Meryl Streep being extremely powerful and moving. It won the Emmy for Best Mini-series 2004; 4 in the actors categories and 12 in total. It\'s overwrought with sadness, pain, and profound loneliness. But it\'s a profound human dimension or existential experience. You\'ll end up saying: "More Life. Let the great work begin."

properties.description: Posted by Gueneviva  Great Neck, NYThis is a fascinating, complex, chilling film. It\'s a documentary about a man accused of child molestation in 1987, made by the man\'s son. Makes a great double feature with "Happiness," if you can stomach it.

properties.name: Dark Days
properties.description: Posted by Gueneviva  In a tunnel between Penn Station and HarlemMarc Singer made this incredible documentary about homeless people living in a Manhattan subway tunnel. One of the most remarkable things about this film is how beautiful it is. I think that Singer is also a still photographer. The film is shot in black and white and very carefully lit. It\'s some of the most beautiful photography I\'ve seen in a movie. The characters are compelling, the story is inspiring and full of drama.

properties.name: Everything Is Illuminated
properties.description: Posted by DeisnorLutsk, UkraineEverything\'s Been Understated in Foer Adaptation Everything Is Illuminated by Michael Atkinson September 13th, 2005 11:55 AM Village Voice Online Store Everything Is Illuminated Written and directed by Liev Schreiber Warner Independent, opens September 16 Utterly unfilmable novels don\'t scare some people�a would-be Cronenberg after a fashion, actor-turned- Yiddishe-auteur Liev Schreiber has fashioned a serviceable, small-boned adaptation of Jonathan Safran Foer\'s inherently defiant, voice-mottled debut book, lean and silly and modest. Not only is Foer\'s language necessarily dropped from the loop�apart from the inevitable narration, giving us a molecular taste of the Ukrainian protagonist\'s chaotic consumer English�but so is the mysterious no-man\'s-land between page and reader, where absurdist ideas are not visualized but can be seen nonetheless. Schreiber jettisons the novel\'s juicy mock-folk shtetl legends and focuses on the "very rigid search" of young American neurotic Foer (Elijah Wood) for the Slavic woman who saved his grandfather from the Nazis. Wood\'s Foer is an anemic straight-man caricature (hardly the precocious nebbish Foer suggested himself to be), and so texture is provided by Eugene Hutz (of Gogol Bordello) as Alex, Foer\'s Odessa hipster guide, and grizzled Russian vet Boris Leskin, as Alex\'s irascible, anti-Semitic, guilt-riddled grandfather. What tale there is left to tell is reduced to driving (through the Czech Republic) and mildly comic culture clash conversation�until the three-man convoy reaches the extinct village where Foer\'s ancestral treasure lies half buried, waiting for rediscovery. Schreiber relies on relentless soundtrack oompah-pah to make the jokes seem like jokes�until the sniffly climax. (Schreiber, like many actor-directors, is indulgent of"heavy" moments of staring and gesture that actually have no weight at all.) Still, Foer\'s ironic ideas have a lovely roundness to them, and somehow the film achieves Holocaust-fiction balance without much ado or melodrama. It may be substantially less ambitious than its source material, but that may be what saves it from implosion.

Sound not so good. But Jeff Towne is so interesting that none of it matters. Even the fact that that the director is a bit of a prick adds something interesting to the film.

properties.name: Shooting Location for The Field of Dreams Film
properties.description: Posted by Echinodermata Dyersville, Iowa1989\'s Field of Dreams was a Best Picture Academy Award nominee, and the baseball field in the cornfield still stands today, and has become quite a tourist destination. Games are occasionally played at the field, re-enacting professional baseball at the turn of the 20th Century.
